speaker: Frasier
text: What is this?  St. Osric's Pre-Kindergartener Academy and Day Care Center?  Do I hear the pitter-patter of petite elite feet?

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, no.  It's just that the wait list for St. Osric's is up to four years.  So I thought we should get our application in now to be safe.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very wise, Niles.  You know, Lilith and I waited until Frederick was conceived before we enrolled him in private school.

speaker: Niles
text: Mr. Procrastinator.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's pre-kindergarten.  They run around, they sing, they nap. I mean, how special can St. Osric's really be?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I hear the top two percent in coloring and putting away can pretty much write their own ticket.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles, guess who's coming to visit?  Leland Barton.

speaker: Niles
text: Really.  From the Empire Club?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, that's Barton Leland.  Leland Barton was Mom's research assistant.  They worked together closely for years.

speaker: Niles
text: I don't remember him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's right.  We were just boys when he moved to France. Apparently he gave up psychiatry and immersed himself in the Paris art world.  Today he sits on the board of the Paris Museum of Modern Art.

speaker: Niles
text: Wow.  It takes a brave man to just chuck it all.  Cross the ocean in pursuit of a new life in a new country.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_getting up_] Or a brave woman.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, yes, that's absolutely right.  That's exactly what you did.

speaker: Frasier
text: Just like Dr. Barton you bade farewell to the comforts of hearth and home and filled your sails with the winds of change and adventure.

speaker: Daphne
text: I never looked at it that way.  Now I'll have something to think about this afternoon when I'm rubbin' your dad's bum.  _She kisses Niles and leaves.  Niles and Frasier consider the "adventure" in that.  Fade out.  Scene 2 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  Frasier opens the door and lets Roz in.  She has Eddie and her dog, Ariel, with her._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Roz, how was the dog park?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I got a phone number.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, nice.

speaker: Frasier
text: Is that why you people have pets?  To get dates?

speaker: Roz
text: No, but it's a plus.  I've never met one person who didn't get at least one date through their pet.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, meet me!  Four years of high school and not a single encounter generated!  Stupid fish.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that'll be Leland.

speaker: Roz
text: Who's Leland?

speaker: Martin
text: He was Hester's research assistant.  Used to follow her around like a puppy.  I think he was always a little bit jealous of me, to be honest.  Not that he was alone.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Barton.

speaker: Leland
text: Hello, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good to see you.  _They shake and Leland comes in.  Frasier grabs his garment bag and Leland gets his captain's bag.  Martin gets up._

speaker: Frasier
text: Let me take that for you.

speaker: Leland
text: Thank you very much.  Thank you.  Hello.  My God, look at you. I haven't seen you since you were about, what, seven years old. And you still look good in a suit.  Martin, you have not changed a whit.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, my hair's gray and I've got a bullet in my hip.

speaker: Leland
text: Well, I'm bigger and balder, but I don't want to hear about it.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you look exactly the same, too.

speaker: Leland
text: And you must be... I'm assuming you don't go by "Niles" anymore.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, this is my producer Roz Doyle.  My brother's not here.

speaker: Leland
text: Ah.  My sincerest apologies.  You are a handsome woman.

speaker: Roz
text: And it's nice to meet you, too.  I guess I should be going.

speaker: Leland
text: Oh, not on my account, I hope.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, Roz, stay if you like.  Can I get anybody a drink?

speaker: Leland
text: Well, not unless you happen to have any sherry.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I think I can scare up a glass.  Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I'll have a beer, please.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I can handle that.

speaker: Roz
text: Come, sit down.

speaker: Leland
text: Thank you.

speaker: Roz
text: So, I hear you worked with Frasier's mom.

speaker: Leland
text: Yes, I did.  Did you know her?

speaker: Roz
text: No.

speaker: Leland
text: Pity.  She was a remarkable woman.  Brilliant, playful, passionate.  I adored her.

speaker: Frasier
text: Here we are.  Welcome back to Seattle.

speaker: Leland
text: Thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: There we are.

speaker: Leland
text: This sherry is exquisite.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you.  It's an Andalusian Amontillado I'm rather fond of.

speaker: Leland
text: A connoisseur.  I'm very surprised.  Most Americans think that sherry is just for cooking.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, my brother and I have always had a taste for it.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you didn't get any of that from me.  I always hated the stuff.  You know, come to think of it, so did your mom.  _Eddie jumps up on the couch next to Leland, puts his paw on his arm, and stares at him.  Leland looks at him questioningly._

speaker: Leland
text: Can I help you?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry about that.

speaker: Martin
text: Eddie, down.

speaker: Leland
text: Why is he doing that?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't really know.  He used to do that to me.  But I'll tell you what, just don't get in a staring contest with him, that's what he wants.

speaker: Martin
text: Come on, Eddie, get down.  I'm sorry, I don't know what got into him.  I'll get him a treat.  _Martin leads Eddie off to the kitchen.  Leland gets up and looks around the apartment._

speaker: Leland
text: Frasier, this is remarkable.  You and I seem to have the same taste in art.  Rauschenberg, Otterson, African statuary and sculpture.  Although, I must confess, I'm not familiar with that one.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's because while most Ashanti statues are intended to ward off evil spirits, this one was designed to distract me while my pockets were picked at the Kinshasa Airport.  _He and Leland share a hearty laugh and then drink at the same time, their poses almost identical.  Roz gets up._

speaker: Roz
text: You two have a lot in common.  Psychiatry and sherry and art...

speaker: Leland
text: And furniture.  That is a Coco Chanel sofa unless I'm mistaken.

speaker: Frasier
text: It is an exact replica of the one in her Paris _atelier_.  You know, not many people even notice it.

speaker: Leland
text: Well, not many people have passed out drunk on the original.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I would love to hear that story.

speaker: Leland
text: Well you are in luck, because I love to tell it.  But first, let me thank you for making me feel so welcome.  I must confess, I had some reservations about returning to Seattle, but you've dispelled them all.  To you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please.  _They sit down on the sofa together, take another sip and both make contented sighs.  Eddie jumps up on the couch between them, looking back and forth, unable to make up his mind.  Martin notices Roz staring at them._

speaker: Martin
text: What's the matter?

speaker: Roz
text: Nothing.  _On the sofa, Eddie continues to stare back and forth between Frasier and Leland.  Fade out._  **THE WOES OF THE NAME**  _Scene 3 - Niles' Apartment Fade in.  Niles and Daphne are working on a pre-school application._

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, we just need to fill in a name and I can get the application over to St. Osric's.

speaker: Daphne
text: How can we have a name?  I'm not even pregnant yet.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, it's not THE name, it's just a place holder.  Anything will do.

speaker: Daphne
text: All right, how about, uh... Simon?

speaker: Niles
text: As in your brother with the substance abuse problem, Simon?

speaker: Daphne
text: There are other Simons, you know.  Simon Templar, Simon Legree... Simon Chipmunk.

speaker: Niles
text: Not exactly building a case for "Simon".  How about Jill?

speaker: Daphne
text: No, don't like it.  That's the name of that weather tart on channel eight.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, let's just pick a name at random.  Like out of the phone book.

speaker: Daphne
text: That's a good idea.  Leave it to fate.

speaker: Niles
text: Okay.  When I stop, you point. _He riffles through the book in front of her and stops with it open. She jabs her finger at the page.  Niles reads the name and sits back down to write it in._

speaker: Niles
text: "Bob."  Great.  "Bob Crane."  Okay, we're going to need some Wite-Out.   _Scene 4 - Cafe Nervosa Fade in.  Leland, Niles, Frasier and Martin walk in the front._

speaker: Leland
text: Oh, listen to me.  I've been talking your ears off for the last hour about psychiatry.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, really.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz, do you mind if we join you?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, yeah, not at all.

speaker: Niles
text: Leland, it is such a pleasure to talk shop with a fellow nutcracker.

speaker: Leland
text: And talking to you Jung people makes me feel like an "id" again.

speaker: Niles
text: Do you have a pun, Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, let's just sit down. _The brothers take seats.  Martin notices Roz staring at Leland, who is dusting his chair._

speaker: Martin
text: What's wrong?

speaker: Roz
text: Nothing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you know, there is a wonderful Brassai exhibit in town. What do you say we stop over there after lunch?

speaker: Leland
text: I would love that.  I'm a big fan.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I wish I could join you, I have patients all afternoon. I don't suppose you'd be willing to go now, would you?

speaker: Leland
text: Oh, fine by me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, certainly, let's go get our coffee at the museum.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, Roz, any chance you'd like to take in some Parisian photos taken by an old Romanian master?

speaker: Martin
text: Hmm... no.

speaker: Roz
text: Thanks, anyway.

speaker: Waitress
text: Oh, excuse me, your father forgot his umbrella.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you very much.  Here you go, "Dad."

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I don't blame her for that.  Leland's more like 'em than I am.

speaker: Roz
text: Really?  You really think so?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, come on.  How can you not see it?  They're like three fancy peas in a pod.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I did notice that they have the same taste in art and music, and they even have some of the same mannerisms.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  And Leland and Niles are both allergic to rose hips and Jerusalem artichokes.  Weird, huh?

speaker: Roz
text: When Leland started talking to me last night about how close he and Hester were, I started thinkin' what you're thinkin'.

speaker: Martin
text: And what am I thinking?

speaker: Roz
text: Nothing.

speaker: Martin
text: What are you saying?  You think he's their father?

speaker: Roz
text: No, I wasn't saying that!

speaker: Martin
text: Lot's of people like art and sherry and French stuff.  It doesn't mean they're related.  By your logic, everyone on the cooking channel is their father.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay.

speaker: Martin
text: Okay!

speaker: Martin
text: Ugh.  What the hell is this?

speaker: Roz
text: I don't know, it was there when I sat down.

speaker: Martin
text: Ugh!   _Scene 5 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  Niles is on the couch, going through a manuscript.  Leland comes out of the powder room._

speaker: Niles
text: Leland, your autobiography is wonderful.

speaker: Leland
text: Thank you. Let us hope that the publishing houses feel similarly.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah.  Have you shown it to Frasier?

speaker: Leland
text: No I haven't.  How's he feeling by the way?

speaker: Niles
text: Let's go see.  Bring the manuscript, he'd love to see it.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello.  Oh, hello, Darling. [_to Leland_] Go ahead, I'll be right there. _Leland walks back towards the bedroom and Niles returns to his phone call._

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, so "Delilah" is out?  No, that's fine, that's fine. What are your ideas? ... Taylor.  Fletcher.  Cooper.  Tanner? Where are you getting these, the Big Book of Medieval Professions?

speaker: Leland
text: Frasier, how are you doing?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm afraid my stomach is still churning.  I'm not going to be able to make dinner.

speaker: Leland
text: Oh, I understand.  Well, I'll leave you to rest.  Perhaps, though, later if you're feeling better I can get your opinion on a short section of my autobiography.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, when I can't give an opinion you may as well call the coroner, tag my toe, I'm dead.  _Leland pulls a chair up.  Cut to - the living room.  Niles is still talking to Daphne._

speaker: Niles
text: No.  That's a kind of car.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hi.

speaker: Martin
text: What's going on?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, we were going to go out to dinner with Leland, but Frasier's not feeling well.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh.  Well, maybe I'll go check on him.

speaker: Niles
text: [_into phone_] Now it just sounds like you're reading from the spice rack.

speaker: Leland
text: "I realized the sherpa had become my guide in more ways than one."

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that was wonderful.  Read me another.

speaker: Leland
text: No, no, go to sleep now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Fraizh.  I just was wonderin' how you were doin'.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well, not so good, actually.  I'm afraid I'm going to have to skip dinner.  Why don't you go in my place?

speaker: Martin
text: Sure, if you want me to.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right.  You know, the two of you should get going, really. You'll miss the reservation.

speaker: Martin
text: Right.  Get well, son.

speaker: Leland
text: We'll be wishing you a speedy recovery.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, Fraizh, you want me to bring you back something from the restaurant?  Maybe some Jell-o to sooth your tummy?

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Dad, it's all taken care of.  Leland's going to bring me some _consomme_ and sorbet.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, okay.  _Martin leaves, disgruntled.  Cut to - the living room as Leland comes in._

speaker: Leland
text: Well, Niles, it looks like your dad is going to take Frasier's place at dinner.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, excellent.

speaker: Leland
text: What's the matter?

speaker: Niles
text: My leg's asleep.

speaker: Leland
text: Oh, move your foot around.

speaker: Niles
text: No, it's the whole leg.  I'll just wait it out.

speaker: Leland
text: But the movement will get the blood flowing.  Go ahead, give it a try.

speaker: Niles
text: No, I can't put weight on it.

speaker: Leland
text: Sure you can.  Give it a try.  Come on, one step at a time. That a boy.  _Martin comes in to watch as Niles walks unsteadily across the room like a child to Leland, finally grabbing him for balance._

speaker: Leland
text: Keep going, there we are.   _Act 2  Scene 1 - KACL Fade in.  Martin is talking to Roz in the booth._

speaker: Roz
text: You really think your wife would have ever cheated on you?

speaker: Martin
text: She did.  She said it happened once.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, my God.  With Leland?

speaker: Martin
text: No, someone else.

speaker: Roz
text: You know, I think that you're driving yourself crazy for nothing here.  Of COURSE Frasier and Niles are your sons. You're exactly like them.

speaker: Martin
text: Like?  How?

speaker: Roz
text: Your strong sense of ethics.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, we are ethical.  What else?

speaker: Roz
text: The way they spin out of control.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, that's true.  They get that from me.

speaker: Roz
text: Their stubbornness.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm not stubborn.

speaker: Roz
text: Their defensiveness.

speaker: Martin
text: What's that supposed to mean?

speaker: Roz
text: The way they completely dismiss anyone who doesn't share their opinion.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, now you're just being dumb.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, what is the worst case scenario?  If you found out you weren't their father, would you love them any less?

speaker: Martin
text: No, no.  Well, yeah, a little maybe, at first.  But no, I... I'd feel the same about them as I hope they would about me.

speaker: Roz
text: Which they would.  And you know that.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  I mean, you'd still love Alice if you found out you'd gotten the wrong baby at the hospital.

speaker: Roz
text: Sure.

speaker: Martin
text: And as a cop, I've seen that happen more often than you'd think.  Especially at Seattle General.

speaker: Roz
text: I had Alice at Seattle General.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, sorry.  But the point was, that you'd love her just the same, so who cares who her real mother is.

speaker: Roz
text: I'M her real mother!

speaker: Martin
text: Okay, geez.   _Scene 2 - Niles' Apartment Fade in.  Niles and Daphne are on the couch, still trying for a hypothetical name._

speaker: Niles
text: How about "Desmond"?

speaker: Daphne
text: Desmond Crane.  "Desmond Crane you are hereby sentenced to..." No, I don't like it.  What about "Jack"?

speaker: Niles
text: 'Fraid not.  The first name ends with the same sound that begins the last name.  So you either run them together "JacKrane", or you face the dreaded glottal stop "JacK Crane", "JacK Crane".  It's unpleasant for the throat.

speaker: Daphne
text: This conversation's unpleasant for the throat.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I know, I know.  Okay... OH!  Why don't we use the name of that nice nurse from when I was in the hospital?

speaker: Daphne
text: "Fong" or "DeShandra"?

speaker: Niles
text: "Fong."

speaker: Niles
text: Well, wait.  Let's not drive ourselves crazy about this.  It's a temporary name for a hypothetical child.

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes, but once you give something a name, it makes it more real.  And then that name will always have a sort of priority. I don't care how often you say "elevator" or "apartment" or "crossing guard," to me they'll always be "lifts" and "flats" and "lollipop men."

speaker: Niles
text: Well then, tell you what.  You pick a name and I'll accept it unconditionally.

speaker: Daphne
text: "Milton".

speaker: Niles
text: "Milton."  Great poet and a great name.

speaker: Daphne
text: Great.  Can we go to bed now?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes....

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, didn't you have a soccer hooligan boyfriend named Milton?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah.  That's where I got it.  _Niles turns on his heel, a look of disdain on his face.  He rushes down the stairs and erases the name.  Fade out._  _Scene 3 - Frasier's Apartment Fade in.  Niles is playing the piano, with Leland and Frasier looking on.  They are singing "Modern Major-General" from "The Pirates of Penzance."_

speaker: Frasier
text: I know the kings of England and I quote the fights historical, From Marathon to Waterloo in order categorical.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm very well acquainted, too, with matters mathematical, I understand equations both the simple and quadratical.

speaker: Leland
text: About binomial theorem I'm teeming with a lot of news, With many cheerful facts about the square of the hypotenuse.

speaker: Together
text: With many cheerful facts about the square of the hypotenuse, With many cheerful facts about the square of the hypotenuse, With many cheerful facts about the square of the hypotenuse!

speaker: Martin
text: With awful facts about the scary hippopotamus!

speaker: Leland
text: What a wonderfully musical family you are.

speaker: Martin
text: We sure are.  Me and my boys.  My boys and me.  We're wonderful and we're musical.

speaker: Leland
text: Martin, I can't tell you what a wonderful job you've done with them.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it wasn't a job, it was a biological pleasure!  And don't forget I had Hester.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, excuse me.

speaker: Leland
text: Well, you were lucky.  She was a splendid woman and a remarkable research partner.

speaker: Martin
text: And an even better life partner.

speaker: Leland
text: Well, I wouldn't know about that.

speaker: Martin
text: [_muttering_] Damn straight you wouldn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: Leland, your cab is waiting.

speaker: Leland
text: Oh, so soon.  Well, I can't thank you enough for all your courtesies.  If you are ever in Paris you must allow me to repay your many kindnesses.  I'm so proud of the way you boys have turned out.

speaker: Martin
text: Leland, let me walk you out.

speaker: Leland
text: Thank you.

speaker: Niles
text: Bon voyage. _Leland and Martin head out to the hallway.  Cut to - the hall as they come out and Leland closes the door._

speaker: Martin
text: Leland, there's a question I need to ask you.

speaker: Leland
text: Yes, of course.  Anything.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm a little uncomfortable even bringing it up, but I don't think I could let you leave the country without knowing the answer.  I know that you and my wife spent a lot of time together.  That you were close...

speaker: Leland
text: I... loved her very much.

speaker: Martin
text: Then I guess my question is: How much?

speaker: Leland
text: Enough to trust her with the fact that I'm gay.

speaker: Leland
text: You know, forty years ago people weren't as accepting as they are nowadays.  And without someone like her to confide in... she quite probably saved my life.

speaker: Martin
text: Leland, she loved you too.

speaker: Leland
text: She really was something, wasn't she?

speaker: Martin
text: She really was.

speaker: Leland
text: Bye, Martin.

speaker: Martin
text: Take care, Leland. _The elevator closes and Martin goes back in.  Cut to - the living room as he enters and sees Frasier and Niles at the piano again._

speaker: Martin
text: My boys.

speaker: His Boys
text: On a tree by a river, a littlie tom-tit Sang "Willow, tit-willow, tit-willow". And I said to him "Dicky-bird, why do you sit? Singing 'Willow, tit-willow, tit-willow'?"  "Is it a weakness of intellect, birdie?" I cried "Or a rather tough worm on your little inside?"  [_"On a Tree By A River," from "The Mikado."_]  _Martin throws his cane down in disgust, plops down in his chair and puts on his headphones, before turning on the TV.  Fade out._  [_N.B. If the characters' ages are meant to reflect the true ages of the actors, then Leland/David Ogden Stiers would have been only fourteen when he was Hester's research assistant._] _Fade in.  Daphne is at the window seat, staring at the St. Osric's application.  Roz walks in._

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, my God, are you still stuck picking a name for that application?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yeah, we can't come up with one.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh God, give it to me.  And then I'll fill it in and you'll never have to see it and you won't feel stuck with it.

speaker: Daphne
text: That's a great idea.   **FIVE YEARS LATER**  _Scene 5 - St. Osric's Pre-kindergartener Academy and Day Care Center Fade in.  The applications committee is meeting._

speaker: Director
text: Howard Clifton is officially accepted.  Who do we have next?

speaker: Committeeman
text: Last name "Crane", first name... "Ichabod".

speaker: Director
text: Well, if they're not going to take the application seriously, how can we expect them to take St. Osric's seriously?  _He stamps it "ADMISSION DENIED" and puts it on the reject pile. Fade out._
